DOC.HEAD: State Investigates Southern Bell Pay Phone Commissions
DOC.TEXT: Florida's attorney general said Wednesday the state is investigating whether Southern Bell underpaid commissions for pay telephone use to governments in several Southeastern states. Attorney General Bob Butterworth said the delinquent commissions could total in the millions of dollars but determining the exact amount has been hampered by the telephone company's inability to provide records. The commissions were to have been paid over two years starting in August 1986. Butterworth said Atlanta-based Southern Bell knew of the problem in February 1987, but did nothing until a report in The Miami Herald last month. ``Computer mistakes do happen,'' he said. ``It is troubling, however, that Southern Bell knew about this problem for more than 2{ years, yet apparently made little effort to reimburse its short-changed government customers.'' Southern Bell contracts with government agencies to put pay phones in buildings and then pays a percentage based on usage. Southern Bell did not immediately return calls seeking comment. Officials previously have denied any wrongdoing and said the mistake was caused by a computer error. Butterworth said the failure to make back-payments promptly could violate the state's grand theft law. Butterworth said he began sending letters Wednesday to federal, state and local agencies advising them not to accept restitution from Southern Bell until his office accounts for the delinquent commissions. ``As soon as we can determine what appears to be owed, we will advise you,'' Butterworth said in one letter. ``You may well be entitled to to a claim exceeding the contract amount plus interest.'' Butterworth said Southern Bell may owe commissions to agencies in Florida, Georgia, North Carolina and South Carolina. In a letter last week to Southern Bell President B. Franklin Skinner, Butterworth said key documents regarding the commissions were lost or destroyed and that the company initially said it could not replace them. Now, however, Southern Bell is ``reconstructing'' those records, he said. Butterworth asked Skinner to ensure that Southern Bell does not attempt to pay restitution and that whatever amount the utility believes it owes be placed in an interest-bearing trust account until the investigation ends. The Herald reported that Southern Bell had underpaid Broward County agencies more than $150,000 in commissions. The newspaper quoted a former utility manager as saying the company knew the revenue reports were wrong.
